tit.e: Kajun-ha group of the Sekishu school
Kajun-ha group of the Sekishu-ryu school (a group of Sekishu-ryu school of Japanese tea ceremony)
Kajun-ha group of the Sekishu-ryu school (a group of Sekishu-ryu school of Japanese tea ceremony)

sen.j: 石州流嘉順派（せきしゅうりゅうかじゅんは）は武家茶道。
sen.e: The Kajun-ha group of the Sekishu school performs the buke-sado (the art of the tea ceremony of samurai families).
The Kajun-ha group of the Sekishu-ryu school performs the buke-sado (the art of the tea ceremony of samurai families).
The Kajun-ha group of the Sekishu-ryu school performs the buke-sado (the art of the tea ceremony of samurai families).
They are a branch of the Sekishu school.
They are a branch of the Sekishu-ryu school.
They are a branch of the Sekishu-ryu school.

sen.j: 石州清水流嘉順派（せきしゅうしみずりゅうかじゅんは）ともいう。
sen.e: They are also referred to as the Kajun-ha group of the Sekishu-Shimizu school.
They are also referred to as the Kajun-ha group of the Sekishu-Shimizu-ryu school.
They are also referred to as the Kajun-ha group of the Sekishu-Shimizu-ryu school.

sen.j: 仙台の石州流清水派（石州清水流ともいう）の分派。
sen.e: This group is descended from the Shimizu-ha group of the Sekishu school (also known as the Sekishu-Shimizu school) which is located in Sendai.
This group is descended from the Shimizu-ha group of the Sekishu-ryu school (also known as the Sekishu-Shimizu-ryu school) which is located in Sendai.
This group is descended from the Shimizu-ha group of the Sekishu-ryu school (also known as the Sekishu-Shimizu-ryu school) which is located in Sendai.

sen.j: 江戸時代は幕府数奇屋組頭を代々世襲し石州流伊佐派、石州流野村派とともに柳営茶道をささえた。
sen.e: During the Edo period, they had handed down a position at the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) called Sukiya-gashira (a person who is responsible for the tea room and equipment for the shogun) for generations, and they supported the Ryuei-chado (the tea ceremony for the Shogunate) in cooperation with the Isa-ha group of the Sekishu school and the Nomura-ha group of the Sekishu school.

During the Edo period, they had handed down a position at the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) called Sukiya-kumigashira (a person who is responsible for the tea room and equipment for the shogun) for generations, and they supported the Ryuei-chado (the tea ceremony for the Shogunate) in cooperation with the Isa-ha group of the Sekishu-ryu school and the Nomura-ha group of the Sekishu-ryu school.
sen.cmt: 読み、用語を変えました。
sen.e: During the Edo period, they had handed down a position at the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) called Sukiya-kumigashira (a person who is responsible for the tea room and equipment for the shogun) for generations, and they supported the Ryuei-chado (the tea ceremony for the Shogunate) in cooperation with the Isa-ha group of the Sekishu-ryu school and the Nomura-ha group of the Sekishu-ryu school.
